pages.title: Metaplectic group
pages.text:
{{Distinguish|text=[[Galois module#Weil–Deligne representations|Weil-Deligne representations]].}}

In [[mathematics]], the '''metaplectic group''' Mp<sub>2''n''</sub> is a [[Double covering group|double cover]] of the [[symplectic group]] Sp<sub>2''n''</sub>. It can be defined over either [[real number|real]] or [[p-adic numbers|''p''-adic numbers]]. The construction covers more generally the case of an arbitrary [[local field|local]] or [[finite field]], and even the [[adele ring|ring of adeles]].

The metaplectic group has a particularly significant infinite-dimensional [[linear representation]], the '''Weil representation'''.<ref>{{cite journal |first=A. |last=Weil |title=Sur certains groupes d'opérateurs unitaires |journal=Acta Math. |volume=111 |year=1964 |pages=143–211 |doi=10.1007/BF02391012}}</ref> It was used by [[André Weil]] to give a representation-theoretic interpretation of [[theta function]]s, and is important in the theory of [[modular form]]s of half-integral weight and the [[theta correspondence]].

==Definition==
The [[fundamental group]] of the [[symplectic group|symplectic Lie group]] Sp<sub>2n</sub>('''R''')  is [[infinite cyclic group|infinite cyclic]], so it has a unique connected double cover, which is denoted Mp<sub>2''n''</sub>('''R''') and called the '''metaplectic group'''.

The metaplectic group Mp<sub>2</sub>('''R''') is ''not'' a [[matrix group]]: it has no [[faithful representation|faithful finite-dimensional representation]]s. Therefore, the question of its explicit realization is nontrivial. It has faithful irreducible infinite-dimensional representations, such as the Weil representation described below.

It can be proved that if ''F'' is any local field other than '''C''', then the symplectic group Sp<sub>2''n''</sub>(''F'') admits a unique [[Perfect group|perfect]] [[Group extension#Central extension|central extension]] with the kernel '''Z'''/2'''Z''', the cyclic group of order 2, which is called the metaplectic group over ''F''.
It serves as an algebraic replacement of the topological notion of a 2-fold cover used when {{nowrap|1=''F'' = '''R'''}}. The approach through the notion of central extension is useful even in the case of real metaplectic group, because it allows a description of the group operation via a certain [[Cocycle (algebraic topology)|cocycle]].

== Explicit construction for ''n'' = 1 ==
In the case {{nowrap|1=''n'' = 1}}, the symplectic group coincides with the [[special linear group]] [[SL2(R)|SL<sub>2</sub>('''R''')]]. This group biholomorphically acts on the complex [[upper half-plane]] by fractional-linear transformations,

: <math> g\cdot z=\frac{az+b}{cz+d}</math> where <math>g = \begin{pmatrix}a&b\\c&d\end{pmatrix}\in \mathrm{SL}_2(\mathbf{R})</math>

is a real 2-by-2 matrix with the unit determinant and ''z'' is in the upper half-plane, and this action can be used to explicitly construct the metaplectic cover of SL<sub>2</sub>('''R''').

The elements of the metaplectic group Mp<sub>2</sub>('''R''') are the pairs (''g'', ''ε''), where <math>g\in \mathrm{SL}_2(\mathbf{R})</math> and ''ε'' is a holomorphic function on the [[upper half-plane]] such that <math>\epsilon(z)^2=cz+d=j(g, z) </math>. The multiplication law is defined by:

:<math> (g_1,\epsilon_1)\cdot (g_2,\epsilon_2)=(g_1 g_2, \epsilon),</math>    where <math>\epsilon(z)=\epsilon_1(g_2\cdot z)\epsilon_2(z).</math>

That this product is well-defined follows from the cocycle relation <math>j(g_1g_2, z) = j(g_1, g_2 \cdot z) j(g_2, z)</math>. The map

:<math> (g,\epsilon)\mapsto g</math>

is a surjection from Mp<sub>2</sub>('''R''') to SL<sub>2</sub>('''R''') which does not admit a continuous section. Hence, we have constructed a non-trivial 2-fold cover of the latter group.

==Construction of the Weil representation==
We first give a rather abstract reason why the Weil representation exists. The [[Heisenberg group]] has an irreducible [[unitary representation]] on a Hilbert space <math>\mathcal H</math>, that is, 
:<math>\rho : \mathbb H(V) \longrightarrow U(\mathcal H)</math>
with the center acting as a given nonzero constant. The [[Stone–von Neumann theorem]] states that this representation is essentially unique: if <math>\rho'</math> is another such representation, there exists an automorphism 
:<math>\psi \in U (\mathcal H)</math> such that <math>\rho' = \mathrm{Ad}_\psi (\rho)</math>.
and the conjugating automorphism is projectively unique, i.e., up to a multiplicative modulus 1 constant. So any automorphism of the Heisenberg group, inducing the identity on the center, acts on this representation <math>\mathcal H</math>—to be precise, the action is only well-defined up to multiplication by a non-zero constant.

The automorphisms of the Heisenberg group (fixing its center) form the [[symplectic group]], so at first sight this seems to give an action of the symplectic group on <math>\mathcal H</math>. However, the action is only defined up to multiplication by a nonzero constant, in other words, one can only map the automorphism of the group to the class <math>[\psi]\in PU(\mathcal H)</math>.
So we only get a homomorphism from the symplectic group to the '''projective''' unitary group of <math>\mathcal H</math>; in other words a [[projective representation]]. The general theory of projective representations then applies, to give an action of some [[Group extension#Central extension|central extension]] of the symplectic group on <math>\mathcal H</math>.  A calculation shows that this central extension can be taken to be a double cover, and this double cover is the metaplectic group.

Now we give a more concrete construction in the simplest case of 
Mp<sub>2</sub>('''R''').  The Hilbert space ''H'' is then the space of all ''L''<sup>2</sup> functions on the reals.  The Heisenberg group is generated by translations and by multiplication by the functions ''e''<sup>''ixy''</sup> of ''x'', for ''y'' real. Then the action of the metaplectic group on ''H'' is generated by the Fourier transform and multiplication by the functions exp(''ix''<sup>2</sup>''y'') of ''x'', for ''y'' real.

== Generalizations ==
Weil showed how to extend the theory above by replacing ℝ by any locally compact group ''G'' that is isomorphic to its [[Pontryagin dual]] (the group of characters).  The Hilbert space ''H'' is then the space of all ''L''<sup>2</sup> functions on ''G''. The (analogue of) the Heisenberg group is generated by translations by elements of ''G'', and multiplication by elements of the dual group (considered as functions from ''G'' to the unit circle).  There is an analogue of the symplectic group acting on the Heisenberg group, and this action lifts to a projective representation on ''H''.  The corresponding central extension of the symplectic group is called the metaplectic group.

Some important examples of this construction are given by:

* ''G'' is a vector space over the reals of dimension ''n''.  This gives a metaplectic group that is a double cover of the [[symplectic group]] Sp<sub>2''n''</sub>('''R''').
* More generally ''G'' can be a vector space over any [[local field]] ''F'' of dimension ''n''. This gives a metaplectic group that is a double cover of the symplectic group Sp<sub>2''n''</sub>(''F'').
*''G'' is a vector space over the [[Adele ring|adeles]] of a [[number field]] (or [[global field]]).  This case is used in the representation-theoretic approach to [[automorphic form]]s.
*''G'' is a finite group. The corresponding metaplectic group is then also finite, and the central cover is trivial.  This case is used in the theory of [[theta functions]] of lattices, where typically ''G'' will be the discriminant group of an [[lattice (group)|even lattice]].
* A modern point of view on the existence of the ''linear'' (not projective) Weil representation over a finite field, namely, that it admits a canonical Hilbert space realization, was proposed by [[David Kazhdan]]. Using the notion of canonical intertwining operators suggested by [[Joseph Bernstein]], such a realization was constructed by Gurevich-Hadani.<ref>{{cite arxiv|eprint=0705.4556|title=Quantization of symplectic vector spaces over finite fields|first1=Shamgar|last1=Gurevich|first2=Ronny|last2=Hadani|date=31 May 2007|publisher=|class=math.RT}}</ref>

pages.title: Neville theta functions
pages.text:
{{for|other θ functions|Theta function (disambiguation)}}

In mathematics, the '''Neville theta functions''', named after [[Eric Harold Neville]],<ref>Abramowitz and Stegun, pp. 578-579</ref> are defined as follows:<ref>Neville (1944)</ref><ref>[http://functions.wolfram.com/EllipticFunctions/NevilleThetaC/02/  wolfram Mathematic]</ref>
<ref>[http://functions.wolfram.com/EllipticFunctions/NevilleThetaD/02/ wolfram math]</ref>

: <math> \theta_c(z,m)=\frac {\sqrt{2\pi}\,q(m)^{1/4}}{m^{1/4}\sqrt {K(m)}}\,\, \sum _{k=0}^\infty (q(m))^{k(k+1)} \cos \left(\frac{( 2k+1) \pi z}{2 K(m)} \right) 
</math>

: <math> \theta_d(z,m)=\frac{\sqrt{2\pi}}{2\sqrt{K(m)}}\,\,\left( 1+2\,\sum _{k=1}^\infty (q(m))^{k^2} \cos \left( \frac {\pi zk}{K(m)} \right) \right)
</math>

: <math> \theta_n(z, m) =\frac {\sqrt {2\pi }}{2(1-m)^{1/4}\sqrt {K(m)}}\,\,\left( 1+2\sum _{k=1}^\infty (-1)^k (q(m))^{k^2} \cos \left(\frac{\pi zk}{K(m)} \right) \right)
</math>

: <math> \theta_s(z, m)=\frac{\sqrt {2\pi}\,q(m)^{1/4}}{m^{1/4}(1-m)^{1/4}\sqrt{K(m)}}\,\, \sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k (q(m))^{k(k+1) } \sin\left(\frac { (2k+1) \pi z}{2K(m)} \right)
</math>

where: K(m) is the complete [[elliptic integral]] of the first kind, K'(m)=K(1-m), and  <math>q(m)=e^{-\pi K'(m)/K(m)}</math> is the elliptic nome.

Note that the functions  θ<sub>p</sub>(z,m) are sometimes defined in terms of the nome ''q(m)'' and written θ<sub>p</sub>(z,q) (e.g NIST<ref name="DLMF20"/>). The functions may also be written in terms of the τ parameter θ<sub>p</sub>(z|τ) where <math>q=e^{i\pi\tau}</math>.

==Relationship to other functions==

The Neville theta functions may be expressed in terms of the Jacobi theta functions<ref name="DLMF20">{{cite web|url=http://dlmf.nist.gov/20|title=NIST Digital Library of Mathematical Functions (Release 1.0.17)|editor-last=Olver|editor-first=F. W. J. |display-editors=etal |date=2017-12-22|publisher=National Institute of Standards and Technology|access-date=2018-02-26 }}</ref>

:<math>\theta_s(z|\tau)=\theta_{23}(0|\tau)\theta_1(z'|\tau)/\theta'_1(0|\tau)</math>
:<math>\theta_c(z|\tau)=\theta_2(z'|\tau)/\theta_2(0|\tau)</math>
:<math>\theta_n(z|\tau)=\theta_4(z'|\tau)/\theta_4(0|\tau)</math>
:<math>\theta_d(z|\tau)=\theta_3(z'|\tau)/\theta_3(0|\tau)</math>

where <math>z'=z/\theta_3(0|\tau)^2</math>.

The Neville theta functions are related to the [[Jacobi elliptic functions]]. If pq(u,m) is a Jacobi elliptic function (p and q are one of s,c,n,d), then

:<math>\operatorname{pq}(u,m)=\frac{\theta_p(u,m)}{\theta_q(u,m)}</math>

==Examples==

Substitute ''z'' = 2.5, ''m'' = 0.3 into the above definitions of  Neville theta functions (using [[Maple (software)|Maple]]) once obtain the following (consistent with results from [[Wolfram Mathematica (software)|wolfram math)]].
*<math>\theta_c(2.5, 0.3)=-0.65900466676738154967 </math><ref>[http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=NevilleThetaC%282.5%2C0.3%29 ]</ref>
*<math> \theta_d(2.5, 0.3)=0.95182196661267561994 </math>
*<math> \theta_n(2.5, 0.3)=1.0526693354651613637 </math>
*<math> \theta_s(2.5, 0.3)=0.82086879524530400536 </math>

==Symmetry==
*<math>\theta_c(z,m)=\theta_c(-z,m)</math>
*<math>\theta_d(z,m)=\theta_d(-z,m)</math>
*<math>\theta_n(z,m)=\theta_n(-z,m)</math>
*<math>\theta_s(z,m)=-\theta_s(-z,m)</math>

pages.title: Oscillator representation
pages.text:
In [[mathematics]], the '''oscillator representation''' is a projective [[unitary representation]] of the [[symplectic group]], first investigated by [[Irving Segal]], David Shale, and [[André Weil]]. A natural extension of the representation leads to a [[semigroup]] of [[contraction (operator theory)|contraction operators]], introduced as the '''oscillator semigroup''' by [[Roger Evans Howe|Roger Howe]] in 1988. The semigroup had previously been studied by other mathematicians and physicists, most notably [[Felix Berezin]] in the 1960s.  The simplest example in one dimension is given by [[SL2(R)|SU(1,1)]]. It acts as  [[Möbius transformation]]s on the extended [[complex plane]], leaving the [[unit circle]] invariant. In that case 
the oscillator representation is a unitary representation of a [[double covering group|double cover]] of SU(1,1) and the oscillator semigroup corresponds to a representation by contraction operators of the semigroup in [[SL2(C)|SL(2,'''C''')]] corresponding to [[Möbius transformation]]s that take the [[unit disk]] into itself. The contraction operators, determined only up to a sign, have [[Kernel (algebra)|kernels]] that are [[Gaussian function]]s. On an [[infinitesimal]] level the semigroup is described  by a cone in the [[Lie algebra]] of SU(1,1) that can be identified with a [[light cone]]. The same framework generalizes to the [[symplectic group]] in higher dimensions, including its analogue in infinite dimensions. This article explains the theory for SU(1,1) in detail and summarizes how the theory can be extended.

==Historical overview==
The mathematical formulation of [[quantum mechanics]] by [[Werner Heisenberg]] and [[Erwin Schrödinger]] was originally in terms of [[Unbounded operator|unbounded]] [[self-adjoint operator]]s on a [[Hilbert space]]. The fundamental operators corresponding to position and momentum satisfy the Heisenberg [[Canonical commutation relation|commutation relations]].  Quadratic polynomials in these operators, which include the [[Quantum harmonic oscillator|harmonic oscillator]], are also closed under taking commutators. A large amount of [[operator theory]] was developed in the 1920s and 1930s to provide a rigorous foundation for quantum mechanics. Part of the theory was formulated in terms of [[unitary group]]s of operators, largely through the contributions of [[Hermann Weyl]], [[Marshall Stone]] and [[John von Neumann]]. In turn these results in mathematical physics were subsumed within mathematical analysis, starting with the 1933 lecture notes of [[Norbert Wiener]], who used the [[heat kernel]] for the harmonic oscillator to derive the properties of the [[Fourier transform]]. The uniqueness of the Heisenberg commutation relations, as formulated in the [[Stone–von Neumann theorem]], was later interpreted within [[group representation theory]], in particular the theory of [[induced representation]]s initiated by [[George Mackey]]. The quadratic operators were understood in terms of a [[Projective unitary group#Representations|projective unitary representation]] of the group SU(1,1) and its [[Lie algebra]]. [[Irving Segal]] and David Shale generalized this construction to the [[symplectic group]] in finite and infinite dimensions: in physics this is often referred to as [[Quantum field theory#Bosons|bosonic quantization]]. [[André Weil]] later extended the construction to [[p-adic Lie group]]s, showing how the ideas could be applied in [[number theory]], in particular to give a group theoretic explanation of [[theta function]]s and [[quadratic reciprocity]]. Several physicists and mathematicians observed the heat kernel operators corresponding to the harmonic oscillator were associated to a [[complexification]] of SU(1,1): this was not the whole of SL(2,'''C'''), but instead a complex semigroup defined by a natural geometric condition. The representation theory of this semigroup, and its generalizations in finite and infinite dimensions, has applications both in mathematics and theoretical physics.<ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989}}</ref>

==Semigroups in SL(2,C)==
The group ''G'' = SU(1,1) is formed of matrices

:<math>\begin{pmatrix}\alpha & \beta  \\ \overline{\beta} & \overline{\alpha}\end{pmatrix}</math>

with

:<math> |\alpha|^2 -|\beta|^2=1.</math>

It is a subgroup of ''G''<sub>''c''</sub> = SL(2,'''C'''), the group of complex 2 × 2 matrices with determinant 1.

If ''G''<sub>1</sub> = SL(2,'''R''') and

:<math>C=\begin{pmatrix}1 & i \\ i & 1\end{pmatrix}</math>

then

:<math>G=CG_1C^{-1},</math>

since the Möbius transformation corresponding ''M'' is the [[Cayley transform]] carrying the [[upper half plane]] onto the unit disk and the real line onto the unit circle.

The group SL(2,'''R''') is generated as an abstract group by

:<math>J=\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0\end{pmatrix}</math>

and the subgroup of lower triangular matrices

:<math>\displaystyle{\begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ b & a^{-1}\end{pmatrix}}</math>

with ''b'' real and ''a'' > 0. Indeed, the [[orbit (group theory)|orbit]] of the vector

:<math> \displaystyle{v=\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}}</math>

under the subgroup generated by these matrices is easily seen to be the whole of '''R'''<sup>2</sup> and the [[stabilizer (group theory)|stabilizer]] of ''v'' in ''G''<sub>1</sub> lies in inside this subgroup.

The Lie algebra <math>\mathfrak{g}</math> of SU(1,1) consists of matrices

:<math> \begin{pmatrix} ix & w \\ \overline{w} & -ix \end{pmatrix}</math>

with ''x'' real.

The period 2 [[automorphism]] σ of ''G''<sub>''c''</sub>

:<math> \displaystyle{\sigma(g)= M \overline{g} M^{-1},}</math>

with

:<math>M = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix},</math>

has fixed point subgroup ''G'' since

:<math>\sigma\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \overline{d} & \overline{c} \\ \overline{b} & \overline{a}\end{pmatrix}.</math>

Similarly the same formula defines a period two automorphism σ of the Lie algebra <math>\mathfrak{g}_c</math> of ''G''<sub>''c''</sub>,  the complex matrices with trace zero. A standard basis of <math>\mathfrak{g}_c</math> over '''C''' is given by

:<math>L_0 =\begin{pmatrix} {1\over 2} & 0 \\ 0 & -{1\over 2}\end{pmatrix},\quad L_{-1}=\begin{pmatrix}0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix},\quad L_{1}=\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ -1 & 0\end{pmatrix}. </math>

Thus for −1 ≤ ''m'', ''n'' ≤ 1

:<math> \displaystyle{[L_m,L_n]=(m-n) L_{m+n}.}</math>

There is a [[direct sum]] decomposition

:<math>\mathfrak{g}_c =\mathfrak{g} \oplus i\mathfrak{g},</math>

where <math> \mathfrak{g}</math> is the +1 eigenspace of σ and <math>i\mathfrak{g}</math> the –1 eigenspace.

The matrices ''X'' in <math>i\mathfrak{g}</math> have the form

:<math> X=\begin{pmatrix} x & w \\ -\overline{w} & -x \end{pmatrix}.</math>

Note that

:<math> -\det X = x^2 -|w|^2.</math>

The cone ''C'' in <math>i\mathfrak{g}</math> is defined by two conditions. The first is that

:<math> \det X < 0.</math>

By definition this condition is preserved under [[Conjugacy class|conjugation]] by ''G''. Since ''G'' is connected it leaves the two components with ''x'' > 0 and ''x'' < 0 invariant. The second condition is that

:<math> x<0.</math>

The group ''G''<sub>''c''</sub> acts by Möbius transformations on the extended complex plane. The subgroup ''G'' acts as automorphisms of the unit disk ''D''. A semigroup ''H'' of ''G''<sub>''c''</sub>, first considered by {{harvtxt|Olshanskii|1981}}, can be defined by the geometric condition:

:<math> g(\overline{D}) \subset D.</math>

The semigroup can be described explicitly in terms of the cone ''C'':<ref>{{harvnb|Hilgert|Neeb|1993|pp=59–60}}</ref>

:<math> H =G\cdot \exp(C) =\exp(C)\cdot G.</math>

In fact the matrix ''X'' can be conjugated by an element of ''G'' to the matrix

:<math>Y=\begin{pmatrix} -y & 0 \\ 0 & y \end{pmatrix}</math>

with

:<math> y=\sqrt{x^2 - |w|^2} > 0.</math>

Since the Möbius transformation corresponding to exp ''Y'' sends ''z'' to ''e''<sup>−2''y''</sup> ''z'', it follows that the right hand side lies in the semigroup. Conversely if ''g'' lies in ''H'' it carries the closed unit disk onto a smaller closed disk in its interior. Conjugating by an element of ''G'', the smaller disk can be taken to have centre 0. But then for appropriate ''y'', the element

:<math> e^{-Y}g</math>

carries ''D'' onto itself so lies in ''G''.

A similar argument shows that the closure of ''H'', also a semigroup, is given by

:<math>\overline{H}= \left \{g\in SL(2,{\mathbf C}) \ : \ gD\subseteq D \right \}=G\cdot \exp{\overline{C}} = \exp{\overline{C}}\cdot G.</math>

From the above statement on conjugacy, it follows that

:<math>H=G A_+ G,</math>

where

:<math>A_+ = \left \{ \begin{pmatrix} e^{-y} & 0 \\ 0 & e^y \end{pmatrix} \ : \ y > 0 \right \}.</math>

If a matrix

:<math>\displaystyle{\begin{pmatrix}a & b \\ c & d\end{pmatrix}}</math>

is in ''H'' then so too are the matrices

: <math>\begin{pmatrix}\overline{a} & \overline{b} \\ \overline{c} & \overline{d}\end{pmatrix},\quad \begin{pmatrix}a & -c \\ -b & d\end{pmatrix},</math>

since the latter is obtained by taking the transpose and conjugating by the diagonal matrix with entries ±1.

Hence ''H'' also contains the matrix

:<math>\displaystyle{\begin{pmatrix}\overline{a} & -\overline{c} \\ -\overline{b} & \overline{d}\end{pmatrix}.}</math>

which gives the inverse matrix if the original matrix lies in SU(1,1).

A further result on conjugacy follows by noting that every element of ''H'' must fix a point in ''D'', which by conjugating by an element of ''G'' can be taken to be 0. Then the element of ''H'' has the form

:<math>M= \begin{pmatrix} a& 0 \\ b & a^{-1} \end{pmatrix}</math>

with

:<math> \displaystyle{|a| < 1}</math>

and

:<math> \displaystyle{|b| < |a|^{-1} - |a|.}</math>

The set of such lower triangular matrices forms a subsemigroup ''H''<sub>0</sub> of ''H''.

Since

:<math>\displaystyle{M\begin{pmatrix} x & 0 \\ 0 & x^{-1}\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x & 0\\ ba^{-1}(x-x^{-1}) & x^{-1}\end{pmatrix}M,}</math>

every matrix in ''H''<sub>0</sub> is conjugate to a diagonal matrix by a matrix ''M'' in ''H''<sub>0</sub>.

Similarly every one-parameter semigroup ''S''(''t'') in ''H'' fixes the same point in ''D'' so is conjugate by an element of ''G'' to a one-parameter semigroup in ''H''<sub>0</sub>.

It follows that there is a matrix ''M'' in ''H''<sub>0</sub> such that

:<math>\displaystyle{MS(t)=S_0(t)M,}</math>

with ''S''<sub>0</sub>(''t'') diagonal. Similarly there is a matrix  ''N'' in ''H''<sub>0</sub> such that

:<math>\displaystyle{S(t)N=NS_0(t),}</math>

The semigroup ''H''<sub>0</sub> generates the subgroup ''L'' of complex lower triangular matrices with determinant 1 (given by the above formula with ''a'' ≠ 0). Its Lie algebra consists of matrices of the form

:<math> Z=\begin{pmatrix} z & 0 \\ w & -z\end{pmatrix}.</math>

In particular the one parameter semigroup exp ''tZ'' lies in ''H''<sub>0</sub> for all ''t'' > 0 if and only if

:<math> \Re z < 0</math>

and

:<math> |\Re z| > {1\over 2} |w|.</math>

This follows from the criterion for ''H'' or directly from the formula

:<math>\displaystyle{\exp Z= \begin{pmatrix} e^z & 0\\ f(z) w & e^{-z} \end{pmatrix}, \qquad f(z)={\sinh z\over z}.}</math>

The exponential map is known not to be [[Surjective function|surjective]] in this case, even though it is surjective on the whole group ''L''. This follows because the squaring operation is not surjective in ''H''. Indeed, since the square of an element fixes 0 only if the original element fixes 0, it suffices to prove this in ''H''<sub>0</sub>. Take α with |α| < 1 and

:<math>\displaystyle{|\alpha +\alpha^{-1}|<|\alpha| +|\alpha^{-1}|.}</math>

If ''a'' = α<sup>2</sup> and

:<math>\displaystyle{b = (1-\delta) (|a|^{-1}-|a|),}</math>

with

:<math>\displaystyle{(1-\delta)^2={|\alpha +\alpha^{-1}|\over |\alpha| +|\alpha^{-1}|}},</math>

then the matrix

:<math> \begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ b & a^{-1}\end{pmatrix}</math>

has no square root in ''H''<sub>0</sub>. For a square root would have the form

:<math> \begin{pmatrix} \alpha & 0 \\ \beta & \alpha^{-1}\end{pmatrix}.</math>

On the other hand,

:<math>\displaystyle{|\beta|={b\over |\alpha+\alpha^{-1}|}={|\alpha|^{-1} -|\alpha|\over 1-\delta} > |\alpha|^{-1} -|\alpha|.}</math>

The closed semigroup <math>\overline{H}</math> is '''maximal''' in SL(2,'''C'''): any larger semigroup must be the whole of SL(2,'''C''').<ref>{{harvnb|Hilgert|Neeb|1993|pp=250–253}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Lawson|1998|pp=146–147}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Ferrara|Mattiolia|Rossic|Toller|1973}}</ref>

In fact if ''S'' is a semigroup properly containing <math>\overline{H}</math> and ''g'' is in ''S'' but not <math> \overline{H}</math> then either:

# The image of the unit circle under ''g'' cuts the unit circle twice.
# The image of the unit disk under ''g'' is disjoint from the unit disk. In this case either the image of the unit circle touches the unit circle or is disjoint. Applying a scaling transformation in ''H'' reduces to case (1).

In case (1) if the circles cut at right angles, pre- and post-multiplying ''g'' by elements of SU(1,1) the image of the unit circle can be taken to be the real axis with the points ±1 fixed. But then ''g'' is the Cayley transform and its square ''k'' is the Möbius transformation ''z''<sup>−1</sup>. Since ''k'' ''H'' ''k'' = ''H''<sup>−1</sup>, ''S'' contains a neighbourhood of the identity and hence is the whole of SL(2,'''C'''). If the circles do not intersect at right angles,  pre- and post-multiplying ''g'' by elements of SU(1,1) the points of intersection may be moved close together with 0 in the crescent formed by the obtuse angles and outside the second circle. Scaling transformations in ''H'' will transform the second circle into a touching interior circle. In between the angle will have been a right angle, for which the previous argument applies.

{{harvtxt|Lawson|1998}} gives another way to prove maximality by first showing that there is a ''g'' in ''S'' sending ''D'' onto the disk ''D''<sup>''c''</sup>, |''z''| > 1. In fact if ''x'' is in ''S'' but not in <math>\overline{H}</math>, then there is a small disk ''D''<sub>1</sub> in ''D'' such that ''x'' ''D''<sub>1</sub> lies in ''D''<sup>''c''</sup>. Then for some ''h'' in ''H'', ''D''<sub>1</sub> = ''hD''. Similarly ''yxD''<sub>1</sub> = ''D''<sup>''c''</sup> for some ''y'' in ''H''. So ''g'' = ''yxh'' lies in ''S'' and sends ''D'' onto  ''D''<sup>''c''</sup>. It follows that ''g''<sup>2</sup> fixes the unit disc ''D'' so lies in SU(1,1). So ''g''<sup>−1</sup> lies in ''S''. If ''t'' lies in ''H'' then ''t'' ''g'' ''D'' contains ''g'' ''D''. Hence ''g''<sup>−1</sup>''t''<sup>−1</sup> ''g'' lies in <math>\overline{H}</math>. So ''t''<sup>−1</sup> lies in ''S'' and therefore ''S'' contains an open neighbourhood of ''1''.  Hence ''S'' = SL(2,'''C''').

Exactly the same argument works for Möbius transformations on '''R'''<sup>''n''</sup> and the open semigroup taking the closed unit sphere ||''x''|| ≤ 1 into the open unit sphere ||''x''|| < 1. The closure is a maximal proper semigroup in the group of all Möbius transformations. When ''n'' = 1, the closure corresponds to Möbius transformations of the real line taking the closed interval [–1,1] into itself.<ref>See:
*{{harvnb|Lawson|1998}}
*{{harvnb|Hilgert|Neeb|1993|pp=48–56}}
</ref>

The semigroup ''H'' and its closure have a further piece of structure inherited from ''G'', namely inversion on ''G'' extends to an [[antiautomorphism]] of ''H'' and its closure, which fixes the elements in exp ''C'' and its closure. For

:<math>\displaystyle{g=\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d\end{pmatrix},}</math>

the antiautomorphism is given by

:<math>\displaystyle{g^+=\begin{pmatrix} \overline{a} & -\overline{c} \\ -\overline{b} & \overline{d}\end{pmatrix}}</math>

and extends to an antiautomorphism of SL(2,'''C''').

Similarly the antiautomorphism

<math>\displaystyle{g^\dagger=\begin{pmatrix} \overline{d} & -\overline{b} \\ -\overline{c} & \overline{a}\end{pmatrix}}</math>

leaves ''G''<sub>1</sub> invariant and fixes the elements in exp ''C''<sub>1</sub> and its closure, so it has analogous properties for the semigroup in ''G''<sub>1</sub>.

==Commutation relations of Heisenberg and Weyl==
Let <math>\mathcal S</math> be the space of [[Schwartz function]]s on '''R'''. It is dense in the [[Hilbert space]] ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') of [[square-integrable function]]s on '''R'''. Following the terminology of [[quantum mechanics]], the "momentum" operator ''P'' and "position" operator ''Q''  are defined on  <math>\mathcal S</math> by

:<math> \displaystyle{Pf(x)=if^\prime(x),\qquad Qf(x)=xf(x).}</math>

There operators satisfy the [[canonical commutation relation|Heisenberg commutation relation]]

:<math>\displaystyle{ PQ-QP=iI.}</math>

Formally both ''P'' and ''Q'' are formally self-adjoint for the inner product on  <math>\mathcal S</math> inherited from ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''').

Two one parameter unitary groups ''U''(''s'') and ''V''(''t'') can be defined on <math>\mathcal S</math> and ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') by

:<math> \displaystyle{U(s)f(x)= f(x-s),\qquad V(t)f(x)=e^{ixt} f(x).}</math>

By definition

:<math> \displaystyle{{d\over ds} U(s)f= iP U(s)f,\qquad {d\over dt} V(t)f=iQV(t)f }</math>

for ''f'' in <math>\mathcal S</math>, so that formally

:<math> \displaystyle{U(s)=e^{iPs},\qquad V(t)=e^{iQt}.}</math>

It is immediate from the definition that the one parameter groups ''U'' and ''V'' satisfy the [[canonical commutation relation|Weyl commutation relation]]

:<math> \displaystyle{U(s)V(t)=e^{-ist}V(t)U(s).}</math>

The realization of ''U'' and ''V'' on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') is called the '''Schrödinger representation'''.

==Fourier transform==
The [[Fourier transform]] is defined on <math>\mathcal S</math> by<ref>{{harvnb|Hörmander|1983|pp=160–163}}</ref>

:<math>\displaystyle{\widehat{f}(\xi)= {1\over \sqrt{2\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x) e^{-ix\xi} \, dx.}</math>

It defines a continuous map of <math>\mathcal S</math> into itself for its natural topology.

[[Contour integration]] shows that the function

:<math>\displaystyle{ H_0(x) ={e^{-x^2/2}\over \sqrt{2\pi}}}</math>

is its own Fourier transform.

On the other hand, integrating by parts or differentiating under the integral,

:<math>\widehat{Pf}=-Q\widehat{f},\qquad \widehat{Qf} =P\widehat{f}.</math>

It follows that the operator on <math>\mathcal S</math> defined by

:<math>\displaystyle{Tf(x)=\widehat{\widehat f}(-x)}</math>

commutes with both  ''Q'' (and ''P''). On the other hand,

:<math>\displaystyle{TH_0=H_0}</math>

and since

:<math>\displaystyle{g(x)={f(x)-f(a)H_0(x)/H_0(a)\over x-a}}</math>

lies in <math>\mathcal S</math>, it follows that

:<math>\displaystyle{T(x-a)g|_{x=a}=(x-a)Tg|_{x=a}=0}</math>

and hence

:<math>\displaystyle{Tf(a)= f(a).}</math>

This implies the [[Fourier inversion formula]]:

:<math> \displaystyle{f(x) ={1\over \sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^\infty \widehat{f}(\xi)e^{ix\xi}\, d\xi}</math>

and shows that the Fourier transform is an isomorphism of <math>\mathcal S</math> onto itself.

By Fubini's theorem

:<math>\displaystyle{\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\widehat{g}(x)\, dx= {1\over \sqrt{2\pi}}\iint f(x)g(\xi)e^{-ix\xi} \,dxd\xi=\int_{-\infty}^\infty \widehat{f}(\xi) g(\xi)\, d\xi.}</math>

When combined with the inversion formula this implies that the Fourier transform preserves the inner product

:<math>\displaystyle{(\widehat{f},\widehat{g}) = (f,g)}</math>

so defines an isometry of <math>\mathcal S</math> onto itself.

By density it extends to a unitary operator on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R'''), as asserted by [[Plancherel's theorem]].

==Stone–von Neumann theorem==
{{see also|Stone–von Neumann theorem}}
Now suppose that ''U''(''s'') and ''V''(''t'') are one parameter unitary groups on a Hilbert space <math>\mathcal H</math> satisfying the Weyl commutation relations

:<math>\displaystyle{U(s)V(t) =e^{-ist} V(t)U(s).}</math>

For ''F''(''s'', ''t'') in <math>\mathcal{S}(\mathbf{R}\times \mathbf{R})</math>, let<ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989|pp=35–36}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|von Neumann|1929}}</ref>

:<math>\displaystyle{F^\vee(x,y)={1\over \sqrt{2\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^\infty f(t,y) e^{-itx}\, dt}</math>

and define a bounded operator on <math>\mathcal H</math> by

:<math>\displaystyle{T(F)=\iint F^\vee(x,x+y)U(x)V(y)\,dxdy.}</math>

Then

:<math>\displaystyle{T(F)T(G)=T(F\star G),\qquad T(F)^*= T(F^*),}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{ F\star G(x,y)=\int F(x,z)G(z,y) \, dz,\qquad F^*(x,y)=\overline{F(y,x)}.}</math>

The operators ''T''(''F'') have an important ''non-degeneracy property'': the linear span of all vectors ''T''(''F'')ξ is dense in <math>\mathcal H</math>.

Indeed, if ''f'' ''ds'' and ''g'' ''dt'' define probability measures with compact support, then the smeared operators

:<math>\displaystyle{U(f)=\int U(s) f(s) \, ds,\qquad V(g)=\int V(t) g(t)\, dt}</math>

satisfy

:<math>\displaystyle{ \|U(f)\|,\, \|V(g)\| \le 1}</math>

and converge in the [[strong operator topology]] to the identity operator if the supports of the measures decrease to 0.

Since ''U''(''f'')V(''g'') has the form ''T''(''F''), non-degeneracy follows.

When <math>\mathcal H</math> is the Schrödinger representation on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R'''), the operator ''T''(''F'') is given by

:<math> T(F)f(x)=\int F(x,y)f(y) \, dy.</math>

It follows from this formula that ''U'' and ''V'' jointly act irreducibly on the Schrödinger representation since this is true for the operators given by kernels that are Schwartz functions.

Conversely given a representation of the Weyl commutation relations on <math>\mathcal H</math>, it gives rise to a non-degenerate representation of the *-algebra of kernel operators. But all such representations are on an orthogonal direct sum of copies of ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') with the action on each copy as above. This is a straightforward generalisation of the elementary fact that the representations of the ''N'' × ''N'' matrices are on direct sums of the standard representation on '''C'''<sup>''N''</sup>. The proof using [[matrix unit]]s  works equally well in infinite dimensions.
 
The one parameter unitary groups ''U'' and ''V'' leave each component invariant, inducing the standard action on the Schrödinger representation.

In particular this implies the '''[[Stone–von Neumann theorem]]''': the Schrödinger representation is the unique irreducible representation of the Weyl commutation relations on a Hilbert space.

==Oscillator representation of SL(2,R)==
Given ''U'' and ''V'' satisfying the Weyl commutation relations, define

:<math>\displaystyle{ W(x,y)=e^{ixy/2}U(x)V(y).}</math>

Then

:<math>\displaystyle{W(x_1,y_1)W(x_2,y_2)=e^{i(x_1y_2-y_1x_2)} W(x_1+x_2,y_1+y_2),}</math>

so that ''W'' defines a projective unitary representation of '''R'''<sup>2</sup> with cocycle given by

:<math>\displaystyle{\omega(z_1,z_2) = e^{iB(z_1,z_2)},}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{z=x+iy=(x,y),}</math>

and ''B'' is the [[symplectic form]] on '''R'''<sup>2</sup> given by

:<math>\displaystyle{ B(z_1,z_2)=x_1y_2-y_1x_2=\Im\, z_1\overline {z_2}.}</math>

By the Stone–von Neumann theorem, there is a unique irreducible representation corresponding to this cocycle.

It follows  that if ''g'' is an automorphism of '''R'''<sup>2</sup> preserving the form ''B'', i.e. an element of SL(2,'''R'''), then there is a unitary π(''g'') on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') satisfying the covariance relation

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi(g) W(z) \pi(g)^* = W(g(z)).}</math>

By [[Schur's lemma]] the unitary π(''g'') is unique up to multiplication by a scalar ζ with |ζ| = 1, so that π defines a projective unitary representation of SL(2,'''R''').

This can be established directly using only the irreducibility of the Schrödinger representation. Irreducibility was a direct consequence of the fact the operators

:<math>\displaystyle{ \iint K(x,y) U(x)V(y) \, dxdy,}</math>

with ''K'' a Schwartz function correspond exactly to operators given by kernels with Schwartz functions.

These are dense in the space of [[Hilbert–Schmidt operator]]s, which, since it contains the finite rank operators, acts irreducibly.

The existence of π can be proved using only the irreducibility of the Schrödinger representation. The operators are unique up to a sign with

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi(gh)=\pm \pi(g)\pi(h),}</math>

so that the 2-cocycle for the projective representation of SL(2,'''R''') takes values ±1.

In fact the group SL(2,'''R''') is generated by matrices of the form

:<math>\displaystyle{g_1=\begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ 0 & a^{-1} \end{pmatrix},\,\, g_2=\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0\\ b & 1\end{pmatrix},\,\, g_3=\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1\\ -1 & 0\end{pmatrix},}</math>
 
and it can be verified directly that the operators

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi(g_1)f(x)=\pm a^{-1/2} f(a^{-1}x),\,\, \pi(g_2)f(x) =\pm e^{-ibx^2} f(x),\,\, \pi(g_3)f(x)=\pm e^{i\pi/8} \widehat{f}(x)}</math>

satisfy the covariance relations above.

The generators ''g''<sub>''i''</sub> satisfy the following [[Bruhat decomposition|Bruhat relations]], which uniquely specify the group SL(2,'''R'''):<ref>{{harvnb|Lang|1985|page=209}}</ref>

:<math>\displaystyle{g_3^2=g_1(-1) ,\,\, g_3 g_1(a)g_3^{-1}=g_1(a^{-1}),\,\, g_1(a) g_2(b) g_1(a)^{-1}=g_2(a^{-2}b),\,\, g_1(a)=g_3 g_2(a^{-1}) g_3 g_2(a) g_3 g_2(a^{-1}).}</math>

It can be verified by direct calculation that these relations are satisfied up to a sign by the corresponding operators, which establishes that the cocycle takes values ±1.

There is a more conceptual explanation using an explicit construction of the [[metaplectic group]] as a double cover of SL(2,'''R''').<ref>{{harvnb|Pressley|Segal|1986}}</ref>

In fact SL(2,'''R''') acts by Möbius transformations on the [[upper half plane]] '''H'''.

Moreover, if

:<math>\displaystyle{g=\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d\end{pmatrix},}</math>

then

:<math>\displaystyle{ {dg(z)\over dz} = {1\over (cz+d)^2}.}</math>

The function

:<math> \displaystyle{m(g,z)=cz+d}</math>

satisfies the 1-cocycle relation

:<math>\displaystyle{m(gh,z)=m(g,hz)m(h,z).}</math>

For each ''g'', the function ''m''(''g'',''z'') is non-vanishing on '''H''' and therefore has two possible holomorphic square roots.

The '''metaplectic group''' is defined as the group

:<math>\displaystyle{Mp(2,\mathbf R)=\{(g,G): \,G(z)^2=m(g,z)\}.}</math>

By definition it is a double cover of SL(2,'''R''') and is connected.

Multiplication is given by

:<math>\displaystyle{(g,G)\cdot (h,H)=(gh,K),}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{K(z)=G(hz)H(z).}</math>

Thus for an element ''g'' of the metaplectic group there is a uniquely determined function  ''m''(''g'',''z'')<sup>1/2</sup> satisfying the 1-cocycle relation.

If <math>\Im z > 0</math>, then

:<math>\displaystyle{f_z(x) = e^{izx^2/2}}</math>

lies in ''L''<sup>2</sup> and is called a '''[[coherent states|coherent state]]'''.

These functions lie in a single orbit of SL(2,'''R''') generated by

:<math>\displaystyle{f_i(x) = e^{-x^2/2},}</math>

since for ''g'' in SL(2,'''R''')

:<math>\displaystyle{ \pi((g^t)^{-1})f_z(x)= \pm m(g,z)^{-1/2}f_{gz}(x).}</math>

More specifically if ''g'' lies in Mp(2,'''R''') then

:<math>\displaystyle{ \pi((g^t)^{-1})f_z(x)= m(g,z)^{-1/2}f_{gz}(x).}</math>

Indeed, if this holds for ''g'' and ''h'', it also holds for their product. On the other hand, the formula is easily checked if ''g<sup>t</sup>'' has the form ''g<sub>i</sub>'' and these are generators.

This defines an ordinary unitary representation of the metaplectic group.

The element (1,–1) acts as multiplication by –1 on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R'''), from which it follows that the cocycle on SL(2,'''R''') takes only values ±1.

==Maslov index==
As explained in {{harvtxt|Lion|Vergne|1980}}, the 2-cocycle on SL(2,'''R''') associated with the metaplectic representation, taking values ±1, is determined by the [[Maslov index]].

Given three non-zero vectors ''u'', ''v'', ''w'' in the plane, their '''Maslov index''' <math>\tau(u,v,w)</math> is defined as the [[metric signature|signature]] of the [[quadratic form]] on '''R'''<sup>3</sup> defined by

:<math>\displaystyle{Q(a,b,c)=abB(u,v)+bcB(v,w) + caB(w,u).}</math>

'''Properties of the Maslov index''':

* it depends on the one-dimensional subpaces spanned by the vectors
* it is invariant under SL(2,'''R''')
* it is alternating in its arguments, i.e. its sign changes if two of the arguments are interchanged
* it vanishes if two of the subspaces coincide
* it takes the values –1, 0 and +1: if ''u'' and ''v'' satisfy ''B''(''u'',''v'') = 1 and ''w'' = ''au'' + ''bv'',  then the Maslov index is zero is if ''ab'' = 0 and is otherwise equal to minus the sign of ''ab''
*<math>\displaystyle{\tau(v,w,z) - \tau(u,w,z) + \tau(u,v,z) -  \tau(u,v,w)=0}</math>

Picking a non-zero vector ''u''<sub>0</sub>, it follows that the function

:<math>\displaystyle{\Omega(g,h)=\exp -{\pi i\over 4}\tau(u_0,gu_0,ghu_0)}</math>

defines a 2-cocycle on SL(2,'''R''') with values in the eighth roots of unity.

A modification of the 2-cocycle can be used to define a 2-cocycle with values in ±1 connected with the metaplectic cocycle.<ref>{{harvnb|Lion|Vergne|1980|pp=73–83}}</ref>

In fact given non-zero vectors ''u'', ''v'' in the plane, define ''f''(''u'',''v'') to be

* ''i'' times the sign of ''B''(''u'',''v'') if ''u'' and ''v'' are not proportional
* the sign of λ if ''u'' =   λ''v''.

If

:<math>\displaystyle{b(g)=f(u_0, gu_0),}</math>

then

:<math>\displaystyle{\Omega(g,h)^2 =b(gh)b(g)^{-1}b(h)^{-1}.}</math>

The representatives π(''g'') in the metaplectic representation can be chosen so that

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi(gh) =\omega(g,h) \pi(g)\pi(h)}</math>

where the 2-cocycle ω is given by

:<math>\displaystyle{\omega(g,h) =\Omega(g,h) \beta(gh)^{-1}\beta(g)\beta(h),}</math>

with

:<math>\displaystyle{\beta(g)^{2}=b(g).}</math>

==Holomorphic Fock space==
{{Main|Segal–Bargmann space}}
'''Holomorphic Fock space''' (also known as the '''Segal–Bargmann space''') is defined to be the vector space <math>\mathcal F</math> of holomorphic functions ''f''(''z'') on '''C''' with

:<math>\displaystyle{{1\over \pi} \iint_{\mathbb C} |f(z)|^2 e^{-|z|^2} \, dxdy}</math>

finite. It has inner product

:<math>\displaystyle{(f_1,f_2)= {1\over \pi} \iint_{\mathbb C} f_1(z)\overline{f_2(z)} e^{-|z|^2} \, dxdy.}</math>

<math>\mathcal F</math>  is a [[Hilbert space]] with orthonormal basis

:<math>\displaystyle{e_n(z)={z^n\over \sqrt{n!}}}</math>

for ''n'' ≥ 0. Moreover, the power series expansion of a holomorphic function in  <math>\mathcal F</math> gives its expansion with respect to this basis.<ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989}}</ref>

Thus for ''z'' in '''C'''

:<math>\displaystyle{ |f(z)| =\left|\sum_{n\ge 0} a_n z^n\right|\le \|f\| e^{|z|^2/2},}</math>

so that evaluation at ''z'' is gives a continuous linear functional on <math>\mathcal F</math>.

In fact

:<math>\displaystyle{ f(a) =(f,E_a)}</math>

where<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2013|pp=299–300}}</ref>

:<math>\displaystyle{E_a(z)=\sum_{n\ge 0} {(E_a,e_n)z^n\over \sqrt{n!}}=\sum_{n\ge 0} {z^n\overline{a}^n\over n!} = e^{z\overline{a}}.}</math>

Thus in particular  <math>\mathcal F</math> is a [[reproducing kernel Hilbert space]].

For ''f'' in <math>\mathcal F</math>  and ''z'' in '''C''' define

:<math>\displaystyle{ W_{\mathcal F}(z)f(w)=e^{-|z|^2/2} e^{w\overline{z}} f(w-z).}</math>

Then

:<math>\displaystyle{W_{\mathcal F}(z_1)W_{\mathcal F}(z_2)= e^{-i\Im z_1\overline{z_2}}  W_{\mathcal F}(z_1+z_2),}</math>

so this gives a unitary representation of the Weyl commutation relations.<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2013|pp=297–299}}</ref> Now

:<math> \displaystyle{W_{\mathcal F}(a)E_0=e^{-|a|^2/2} E_a.}</math>

It follows that the representation <math>W_{\mathcal F}</math> is irreducible.

Indeed, any function orthogonal to all the ''E''<sub>''a''</sub> must vanish, so that their linear span is dense in <math>\mathcal F</math>.

If ''P'' is an orthogonal projection commuting with ''W''(''z''), let ''f'' = ''P'' ''E''<sub>0</sub>. Then

:<math>\displaystyle{f(z)=(PE_0,E_z)=e^{|z|^2}(PE_0,W_{\mathcal F}(z)E_0)=(PE_{-z},E_0)=\overline{f(-z)}.}</math>

The only holomorphic function satisfying this condition is the constant function. So

:<math> \displaystyle{PE_0=\lambda E_0},</math>

with λ = 0 or 1. Since ''E''<sub>0</sub> is cyclic, it follows that ''P'' = 0 or ''I''.

By the [[Stone–von Neumann theorem]] there is a unitary operator <math>\mathcal U</math>  from ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') onto <math>\mathcal F</math>, unique up to multiplication by a scalar, intertwining the two representations of the Weyl commutation relations. By [[Schur's lemma]] and the [[Gelfand–Naimark construction]], the matrix coefficient of any vector determines the vector up to a scalar multiple. Since the matrix coefficients of ''F'' = ''E''<sub>0</sub> and ''f'' = ''H''<sub>0</sub> are equal, it follows that the unitary <math>\mathcal U</math> is uniquely determined by the properties

:<math>\displaystyle{W_{\mathcal F}(a) \mathcal{U} = \mathcal{U} W(a)}</math>

and

:<math>\displaystyle{\mathcal{U}H_0 = E_0.}</math>

Hence for ''f'' in ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''')

:<math>\displaystyle{\mathcal{U}f(z)= (\mathcal{U}f,E_z) = (f,\mathcal{U}^* E_z) = e^{-|z|^2}(f,  \mathcal{U}^* W_{\mathcal F}(z)E_0) =e^{-|z|^2}(W(-z)f,H_0),}</math>

so that

:<math>\displaystyle{\mathcal{U}f(z) ={1\over \sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-(x^2 +y^2)} e^{-2ixy}f(t+x) e^{-t^2/2} \, dt ={1\over \sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^\infty B(z,t) f(t)\, dt,}</math>

where

:<math> \displaystyle{B(z,t)= \exp \,[-z^2 -t^2/2 +zt].}</math>

The operator <math>\mathcal U</math> is called the [[Segal–Bargmann space#The Segal–Bargmann transform|Segal–Bargmann transform]]<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2013|pp=300–301}}</ref> and ''B'' is called the '''Bargmann kernel'''.<ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989}}</ref>

The adjoint of  <math>\mathcal U</math> is given by the formula:

:<math>\displaystyle{\mathcal{U}^*F(t)={1\over \pi} \iint_{\mathbf C} B(\overline{z},t) F(z)\, dx dy.}</math>

==Fock model==
The action of SU(1,1) on holomorphic Fock space was described by {{harvtxt|Bargmann|1970}} and {{harvtxt|Itzykson|1967}}.

The metaplectic double cover of SU(1,1) can be constructed explicitly as pairs (''g'', γ) with

:<math>\displaystyle{g=\begin{pmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ \overline{\beta} & \overline{\alpha} \end{pmatrix}}</math>

and

:<math>\displaystyle{\gamma^2=\alpha.}</math>

If ''g'' = ''g''<sub>1</sub>''g''<sub>2</sub>, then

:<math>\displaystyle{\gamma = \gamma_1\gamma_2\left(1 +{\beta_1\overline{\beta_2}\over \alpha_1\alpha_2}\right)^{1/2},}</math>

using the power series expansion of (1 + ''z'')<sup>1/2</sup> for |''z''| < 1.

The metaplectic representation is a unitary representation π(''g'', γ) of this group satisfying the covariance relations

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi(g,\gamma) W_{\mathcal F}(z) \pi(g,\gamma)^*=  W_{\mathcal F}(g\cdot z),}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{g\cdot z=\alpha z + \beta \overline{z}.}</math>

Since <math>\mathcal F</math> is a [[reproducing kernel Hilbert space]], any bounded operator ''T'' on it corresponds to a kernel given by a power series of its two arguments. In fact if

:<math>\displaystyle{K_T(a,b)=(TE_{\overline{b}},E_a),}</math>

and ''F'' in <math>\mathcal F</math>, then

:<math>TF(a)=(TF,E_a)=(F,T^*E_a)=\frac{1}{\pi} \iint_{\mathbf C} F(z)\overline{(T^*E_a,E_z)} e^{-|z|^2}\, dx dy=\frac{1}{\pi} \iint_{\mathbf C} K_T(a,\overline{z}) F(z)e^{-|z|^2}\, dxdy.</math>

The covariance relations and analyticity of the kernel imply that for ''S'' = π(''g'', γ),

:<math> \displaystyle{K_S(a,z)=C \cdot \exp\,{1\over 2\alpha}(\overline{\beta} z^2 + 2az - \beta a^2)}</math>

for some constant ''C''. Direct calculation shows that

:<math>\displaystyle{C=\gamma^{-1}}</math>

leads to an ordinary representation of the double cover.<ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989|pp=181–184}}</ref>

Coherent states can again be defined as the orbit of ''E''<sub>0</sub> under the metaplectic group.

For ''w'' complex, set

:<math>\displaystyle{ F_w(z)=e^{wz^2/2}.}</math>

Then ''F''<sub>''w''</sub> lies in <math> \mathcal F</math> if and only if |''w''| < 1.

In particular ''F''<sub>0</sub> = 1 = ''E''<sub>0</sub>.

Moreover,

:<math>\pi(g,\gamma)F_w= (\overline{\alpha} +\overline{\beta}w)^{-\frac{1}{2}} F_{gw}=\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}} \left(1+{\overline{\beta}\over \overline{\alpha}}w\right)^{-1/2}F_{gw},</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{gw={\alpha w + \beta\over \overline{\beta}w + \overline{\alpha}} .}</math>

Similarly the functions ''zF''<sub>''w''</sub> lie in <math> \mathcal F</math> and form an orbit of the metaplectic group:

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi(g,\gamma)[zF_w](z)= (\overline{\alpha} +\overline{\beta}w)^{-3/2} zF_{gw}(z).}</math>

Since (''F''<sub>''w''</sub>, ''E''<sub>0</sub>) = 1, the matrix coefficient of the function ''E''<sub>0</sub> = 1 is given by<ref>{{harvnb|He|2007}}</ref>

:<math>\displaystyle{(\pi(g,\gamma)1,1)=\gamma^{-1}.}</math>

==Disk model==
The projective representation of SL(2,'''R''') on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') or on <math>\mathcal F</math> break up as a direct sum of two irreducible representations, corresponding to even and odd functions of ''x'' or ''z''. The two representations can be realized on Hilbert spaces of holomorphic functions on the unit disk; or, using the Cayley transform, on the upper half plane.<ref>{{harvnb|Itzykson|1967}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989}}</ref>

The even functions correspond to holomorphic functions ''F''<sub>+</sub> for which

:<math>\displaystyle{ {1\over 2\pi}\iint |F_+(z)|^2 (1-|z|^2)^{-1/2} \,dx dy+ {2\over \pi} \iint |F^\prime_+(z)|^2(1-|z|^2)^{\frac{1}{2}} \, dxdy}</math>

is finite; and the odd functions to holomorphic functions ''F''<sub>–</sub> for which

:<math>\displaystyle{{1\over 2\pi}\iint |F_-(z)|^2 (1-|z|^2)^{-1/2} \,dx dy}</math>

is finite. The polarized forms of these expressions define the inner products.

The action of the metaplectic group is given by

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi_\pm(g^{-1})F_\pm(z)= (\overline{\beta} z + \overline{\alpha})^{-1\pm 1/2} F_\pm(gz)}</math>

if ''g'' corresponds to the matrix

:<math>\displaystyle{\begin{pmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ \overline{\beta} & \overline{\alpha}\end{pmatrix}.}</math>

This gives the explicit formula

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi_\pm(g)F_\pm(z)= (-\overline{\beta} z + \alpha )^{-1\pm 1/2} F_\pm\left({\overline{\alpha} z -\beta\over -\overline{\beta} z + \alpha}\right).}</math>

Irreducibility of these representations is established in a standard way.<ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989|page=94}}</ref> Each representation breaks up as a direct sum of one dimensional eigenspaces of the rotation group each of which is generated by a ''C''<sup>∞</sup> vector for the whole group. It follows that any closed invariant subspace is generated by the algebraic direct sum of eigenspaces it contains and that this sum is invariant under the infinitesimal action of the Lie algebra <math>\mathfrak g</math>. On the other hand, that action is irreducible.

The isomorphism with even and odd functions in <math>\mathcal F</math> can be proved using the [[Gelfand–Naimark construction]] since the matrix coefficients associated to ''1'' and ''z'' in the corresponding representations are proportional. {{harvtxt|Itzykson|1967}} gave another method starting from the maps

:<math>U_+(F)(w)=\frac{1}{\pi} \iint_{\mathbf C} F(z) e^{\frac{1}{2} w\overline{z}^2} e^{-|z|^2} \, dx dy,</math>
:<math>U_-(F)(w)=\frac{1}{\pi} \iint_{\mathbf C} F(z) \overline{z}e^{\frac{1}{2} w \overline{z}^2} e^{-|z|^2} \, dx dy,</math>

from the even and odd parts to functions on the unit disk. These maps intertwine the actions of the metaplectic group given above and send ''z''<sup>''n''</sup> to a multiple of ''w''<sup>''n''</sup>. Stipulating that ''U''<sub>±</sub> should be unitary determines the inner products on functions on the disk, which can expressed in the form above.<ref>{{harvtxt|Folland|1989|pp=210–215}}</ref>

Although in these representations the operator ''L''<sub>0</sub> has positive spectrum—the feature that distinguishes the holomorphic [[discrete series representation]]s of SU(1,1)—the representations do not lie in the discrete series of the metaplectic group. Indeed, {{harvtxt|Kashiwara|Vergne|1978}} noted that the matrix coefficients are not square integrable, although their third power is.<ref>{{harvnb|He|2007}}</ref>

==Harmonic oscillator and Hermite functions==
Let <math>\mathcal H</math> be the space of functions in ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') of the form

:<math>f(x)=p(x)e^{-\frac{x^2}{2}},</math>

with ''p'' a polynomial.

The operators

:<math>\displaystyle{X =Q-iP={d\over dx} + x,\,\,\,\, Y=Q+iP =-{d\over dx} +x}</math>

act on <math>\mathcal H</math> and satisfy

:<math>\displaystyle{X=Y^*,\,\,\, XY-YX=2I.}</math>

''X'' is called the '''annihilation operator''' and ''Y'' the '''creation operator'''.

So

:<math>\displaystyle{XY=P^2 +Q^2 + I = D +I.}</math>

Then the functions

:<math>\displaystyle{F_n(x) = Y^n e^{-x^2/2}}</math>

satisfy

:<math>\displaystyle{DF_n=(2n+1)F_n.}</math>

Indeed, it follows by induction that

:<math>\displaystyle{XY^n-Y^nX=2n Y^{n-1}}</math>

so that

:<math>\displaystyle{DF_n=(XY-I)Y^nF_0=(Y^{n+1}X +(2n+1)Y^n)F_0 =(2n+1)F_n,}</math>

since ''XF''<sub>0</sub> = 0.

Then

:<math>\displaystyle{\|F_n\|^2_2=2^n n!\sqrt{\pi},}</math>

since this is known for ''n'' = 0 and the commutation relation above yields

:<math>\displaystyle{(F_n,F_n)=(XY^n F_0,Y^{n-1}F_0)=2n (F_{n-1},F_{n-1}).}</math>

The ''n''th [[Hermite function]] is defined by

:<math>\displaystyle{H_n(x)=\|F_n\|^{-1}F_n(x) =p_n(x) e^{-x^2/2}.}</math>

''p''<sub>''n''</sub> is called the ''n''th [[Hermite polynomial]].

They are thus eigenfunctions of the harmonic oscillator:

:<math>\displaystyle{D=-{d^2\over dx^2} + x^2.}</math>

Let

:<math>\displaystyle{A={1\over\sqrt{2}}Y={1\over\sqrt{2}}\left(-{d\over dx} +x\right),\,\,\,A^*={1\over\sqrt{2}}X={1\over\sqrt{2}}\left({d\over dx} +x\right).}</math>

Thus

:<math>\displaystyle{AA^*-A^*A=I.}</math>

The operators ''P'', ''Q'' or equivalently ''A'', ''A''* act irreducibly on <math>\mathcal H</math> by a standard argument.<ref>{{harvnb|Howe|Tan|1992}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Kac|Raina|1987}}</ref>

Indeed, under the unitary isomorphism with holomorphic Fock space  <math>\mathcal H</math> can be identified with '''C'''[''z''], the space of polynomials in ''z'', with

:<math>A= \frac{\partial}{\partial z},\qquad A^*=z.</math>

If a subspace invariant under ''A'' and ''A*'' contains a non-zero polynomial ''p''(''z''), then, applying a power of ''A''*, it contains a non-zero constant; applying then a power of ''A'', it contains all ''z''<sup>''n''</sup>.

Under the isomorphism ''F''<sub>''n''</sub> is sent to a multiple of ''z''<sup>''n''</sup> and the operator ''D'' is given by

:<math>\displaystyle{D=2A^*A+I.}</math>

Let

:<math>\displaystyle{L_0={1\over 2}A^*A={1\over 2} z{\partial\over\partial z}}</math>

so that

:<math>\displaystyle{L_0z^n={n\over 2}z^n.}</math>

In the terminology of physics ''A'', ''A''* give a single boson and ''L''<sub>0</sub> is the energy operator. It is diagonalizable with eigenvalues 0, 1/2, 1, 3/2, ...., each of multiplicity one. Such a representation is called a '''positive energy representation'''.

Moreover,

:<math>\displaystyle{[L_0,A]=-{1\over 2}A,\,\,\, [L_0,A^*]={1\over 2} A^*,}</math>

so that the Lie bracket with ''L''<sub>0</sub> defines a [[derivation (abstract algebra)|derivation]] of the Lie algebra spanned by ''A'', ''A''* and ''I''. Adjoining ''L''<sub>0</sub>
gives the [[semidirect product]]. The infinitesimal version of the Stone–von Neumann theorem states that the above representation on '''C'''[''z''] is the unique irreducible positive energy representation of this Lie algebra with ''L''<sub>0</sub> = ''A''*''A''. For ''A'' lowers energy and ''A''* raises energy. So any lowest energy vector ''v'' is annihilated by ''A'' and the module is exhausted by the powers of ''A''* applied to ''v''. It is thus a non-zero quotient of '''C'''[''z''] and hence can be identified with it by irreducibility.

Let

:<math>\displaystyle{L_{-1}={1\over 2}A^2,\,\,\, L_{1}={1\over 2} A^{*2},}</math>

so that

:<math>\displaystyle{[L_{-1},A]=0,\,\,\, [L_{-1},A^*]=A,\,\,\, [L_1,A]=-A^*, \,\,\, [L_1,A^*]=0.}</math>

These operators satisfy:

:<math>\displaystyle{[L_m,L_n]=(m-n)L_{m+n}}</math>

and act by derivations on the Lie algebra spanned by ''A'', ''A''* and ''I''.

They are the infinitesimal operators corresponding to the metaplectic representation of SU(1,1).

The functions ''F''<sub>''n''</sub> are defined by

:<math>\displaystyle{F_n(x)= \left(x-{d\over dx}\right)^n e^{-x^2/2} = (-1)^ne^{x^2/2} {d^ne^{-x^2}\over dx^n} =(2^nx^n + \cdots )e^{-x^2/2}.}</math>

It follows that the Hermite functions are the orthonormal basis obtained by applying the [[Gram-Schmidt process|Gram-Schmidt orthonormalization process]] to the basis 
''x''<sup>''n''</sup> exp -''x''<sup>2</sup>/2 of <math>\mathcal H</math>.

The completeness of the Hermite functions follows from the fact that the Bargmann transform is unitary and carries the orthonormal basis ''e''<sub>''n''</sub>(''z'') of holomorphic Fock space onto the ''H''<sub>''n''</sub>(''x'').

The heat operator for the harmonic oscillator is the operator on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') defined as the diagonal operator

:<math>\displaystyle{e^{-Dt}H_n=e^{-(2n+1)t}H_n.}</math>

It corresponds to the heat kernel given by '''[[Mehler's formula]]''':

:<math>K_t(x,y)\equiv\sum_{n\ge 0} e^{-(2n+1)t}H_n(x)H_n(y)=(4\pi t)^{-{1\over 2}} \left({2t\over \sinh 2t}\right)^{1\over 2} \exp  \left(-{1\over 4t} \left[{2t\over \tanh 2t}(x^2+y^2) - {2t\over \sinh 2t}(2xy)\right]\right).</math>

This follows from the formula

:<math>\displaystyle{\sum_{n\ge 0} s^n H_n(x)H_n(y)= {1\over \sqrt{\pi(1-s^2)}} \exp {4xys - (1+s^2)(x^2+y^2)\over 2(1-s^2)}.}</math>

To prove this formula note that if ''s'' = σ<sup>2</sup>, then by [[Taylor's formula]]

:<math>F_{\sigma,x}(z)\equiv \sum_{n\ge 0} \sigma^n e_n(z) H_n(x)= \pi^{-{1\over 4}} e^{-\frac{x^2}{2}}\sum_{n\ge 0} {(-z)^n \sigma^n \over 2^n n!}{d^n e^{x^2}\over dx^n} = \pi^{-\frac{1}{4}} \exp (-{x^2\over 2} +\sqrt{2} xz\sigma -{z^2\sigma^2\over 2}).</math>

Thus ''F''<sub>σ,''x''</sub> lies in holomorphic Fock space and

:<math>\displaystyle{\sum_{n\ge 0} s^n H_n(x)H_n(y) = (F_{\sigma,x},F_{\sigma,y})_{\mathcal F},}</math>

an inner product that can be computed directly.

{{harvtxt|Wiener|1933|pp=51–67}} establishes Mehler's formula directly and uses a classical argument to prove that

:<math>\displaystyle{\int K_t(x,y)f(y)\, dy}</math>

tends to ''f'' in ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') as ''t'' decreases to 0. This shows the completeness of the Hermite functions and also, since

:<math>\displaystyle{\widehat{H_n}=(-i)^n H_n,}</math>

can be used to derive the properties of the Fourier transform.

There are other elementary methods for proving the completeness of the Hermite functions, for example using [[Fourier series]].<ref>{{harvnb|Igusa|1972}}</ref>

==Sobolev spaces==
Let

:<math> \displaystyle{P=i{d\over dx},\,\,\, Q=x}</math>

on <math>\mathcal S</math> and let

:<math>\displaystyle{D=P^2+Q^2=-{d^2\over dx^2} + x^2}</math>

be the harmonic oscillator.

The associated '''Sobolev spaces''' ''H''<sub>''s''</sub>, sometimes called '''Hermite-Sobolev spaces''', are defined to

be the completions of <math>\mathcal S</math> with respect to the norms

:<math>\displaystyle{\|f\|_{(s)}^2 = \sum_{n\ge 0} |a_n|^2 (1+2n)^s,}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{f=\sum a_n H_n}</math>

is the expansion of ''f'' in Hermite functions.<ref>{{harvnb|Sohrab|1981}}</ref>

Thus

:<math> \displaystyle{\|f\|_{(s)}^2 = (D^s f,f),\,\,\, (f_1,f_2)_{(s)}=(D^s f_1,f_2).}</math>

The spaces are Hilbert spaces.

Moreover, ''H''<sub>''s''</sub> and ''H''<sub>–''s''</sub> are in duality under the pairing

:<math> \displaystyle{\langle f_1, f_2\rangle = \int f_1f_2 \, dx.}</math>

For ''s'' ≥ 0,

<math>\displaystyle{\|(aP +b Q)f\|_{(s)}\le (|a| + |b|) C_s \|f\|_{(s+{1\over 2})}}</math>

for some positive constant ''C''<sub>''s''</sub>.

Indeed, such an inequality can be checked for creation and annihilation operators acting on Hermite functions ''H''<sub>''n''</sub>  and this implies the general inequality.<ref>{{harvnb|Goodman|Wallach|1984}}</ref>

It follows for arbitrary ''s'' by duality.

Consequently, for a quadratic polynomial ''R'' in ''P'' and ''Q''

:<math>\displaystyle{ \|Rf\|_{(s)}\le C_s^\prime \|f\|_{(s+1)}.}</math>

The [[Sobolev inequality]] holds for ''f'' in ''H''<sub>''s''</sub> with ''s'' > 1/2:

:<math>\displaystyle{|f(x)|\le C_{s,k} \|f\|_{(s+k)} (1+x^2)^{-k}}</math>

for any ''k'' ≥ 0.

Indeed, the result for general ''k'' follows from the case ''k'' = 0 applied to ''Q''<sup>''k''</sup>''f''.

For ''k'' = 0 the Fourier inversion formula

:<math>\displaystyle{ f(x) = {1\over \sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^\infty \widehat{f}(t) e^{itx}\, dt}</math>

implies

:<math>\displaystyle{|f(x)|\le C \left(\int |\widehat{f}(t)|^2 (1+t^2)^s\, dt\right)^{1\over 2}= C((I+Q^2)^s\widehat{f},\widehat{f})^{1\over 2}\le C^\prime \|\widehat{f}\|_{(s)} =C^\prime \|f\|_{(s)}.}</math>

If ''s'' < ''t'', the diagonal form of ''D'', shows that the inclusion of ''H''<sub>''t''</sub> in ''H''<sub>''s''</sub> is compact (Rellich's lemma).

It follows from Sobolev's inequality that the intersection of the spaces ''H''<sub>''s''</sub> is <math>\mathcal S</math>. Functions in <math>\mathcal S</math> are characterized by the rapid decay of their Hermite coefficients ''a''<sub>''n''</sub>.

Standard arguments show that each Sobolev space is invariant under the operators ''W''(''z'') and the metaplectic group.<ref>{{harvnb|Goodman|Wallach|1984}}</ref>

Indeed, it is enough to check invariance when ''g'' is sufficiently close to the identity.

In that case

:<math> \displaystyle{gDg^{-1}=D + A}</math>

with ''D'' + ''A'' an isomorphism from ''H''<sub>''t''+2</sub> to ''H''<sub>''t''</sub>.

It follows that

:<math>\displaystyle{\|\pi(g)f\|^2_{(s)} =|((D+A)^sf,f)| \le  \|(D+A)^sf\|_{(-s)}\cdot\|f\|_{(s)} \le C\|f\|_{(s)}^2.}</math>

If ''f'' is in ''H''<sub>''s''</sub>, then

:<math>\displaystyle{{d\over ds} U(s)f=iPU(s)f,\,\,\, {d\over dt}V(t) f=iQV(t)f,}</math>

where the derivatives lie in ''H''<sub>''s''–½</sub>.

Similarly the partial derivatives of total degree ''k'' of ''U(s)V(t)f'' lie in Sobolev spaces of order ''s''–''k''/2.

Consequently,  a monomial in ''P'' and ''Q'' of order ''2k'' applied to ''f'' lies in ''H''<sub>''s''–''k''</sub> and can be expressed as a linear combination of partial derivatives of ''U(s)V(t)f'' of degree ≤ ''2k'' evaluated at 0.

==Smooth vectors==
The '''smooth vectors''' for the Weyl commutation relations are those ''u'' in ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') such that the map

:<math> \displaystyle{\Phi(z)=W(z)u}</math>

is smooth. By the [[uniform boundedness theorem]], this is equivalent to the requirement that each matrix coefficient ''(W(z)u,v)'' be smooth.

A vector is smooth if and only it lies in <math>\mathcal S</math>.<ref>{{harvnb|Goodman|1969}}</ref> Sufficiency is clear. For necessity, smoothness implies that the partial derivatives of ''W(z)u'' lie in ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''') and hence also ''D<sup>k</sup> u'' for all positive ''k''. Hence ''u'' lies in  the intersection of the ''H<sub>k</sub>'', so in  <math>\mathcal S</math>.

It follows that smooth vectors are also smooth for the metaplectic group.

Moreover, a vector is in <math>\mathcal S</math> if and only if it is a smooth vector for the rotation subgroup of SU(1,1).

==Analytic vectors==
If Π(''t'') is a one parameter unitary group and for ''f'' in <math>\mathcal S</math>

:<math>\displaystyle{ \Pi(f)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(t)\Pi(t)\, dt,}</math>

then the vectors Π(''f'')ξ form a dense set of smooth vectors for Π.

In fact taking

:<math>\displaystyle{ f_\varepsilon(x)= {1\over \sqrt{2\pi \varepsilon}} e^{-x^2/2\varepsilon}}</math>

the vectors ''v'' = Π(''f''<sub>ε</sub>)ξ converge to ξ as ε decreases to 0 and

:<math>\displaystyle{ \Phi(t)=\Pi(t)v}</math>

is an analytic function of ''t'' that extends to an [[entire function]] on '''C'''.

The vector is called an '''entire vector''' for Π.

The wave operator associated to the harmonic oscillator is defined by

:<math> \displaystyle{\Pi(t) = e^{it\sqrt{D}}.}</math>

The operator is diagonal with the Hermite functions ''H''<sub>''n''</sub> as eigenfunctions:

:<math>\displaystyle{\Pi(t) H_n = e^{i(2n+1)^{1\over 2} t} H_n.}</math>

Since it commutes with ''D'', it preserves the Sobolev spaces.

The analytic vectors constructed above can be  rewritten in terms of the Hermite semigroup as

:<math>\displaystyle{v=e^{-\varepsilon D}\xi.}</math>

The fact that ''v'' is an entire vector for Π is equivalent to the summability condition

:<math> \displaystyle{\sum_{n\ge 0} {r^n \|D^{n \over 2}v\|\over n!} < \infty}</math>

for all ''r'' > 0.

Any such vector is also an entire vector for ''U(s)V(t)'', that is the map

:<math>\displaystyle{F(s,t)=U(s)V(t)v}</math>

defined on '''R'''<sup>2</sup> extends to an analytic map on '''C'''<sup>2</sup>.

This reduces to the power series estimate

:<math>\displaystyle{\left\|\sum_{m,n\ge 0} {1\over m! n!}z^m w^n P^m Q^n v\right\| \le C \sum_{k\ge 0} {(|z|+|w|)^k \over k!} \|D^{k\over 2} v\| <\infty.}</math>

So these form a dense set of entire vectors for ''U(s)V(t)''; this can also be checked directly using Mehler's formula.

The spaces of smooth and entire vectors for ''U(s)V(t)'' are each by definition invariant under the action of the metaplectic group as well as the Hermite semigroup.

Let

:<math> \displaystyle{W(z,w)=e^{-izw/2} U(z)V(w)}</math>

be the analytic continuation of the operators ''W''(''x'',''y'') from '''R'''<sup>2</sup> to '''C'''<sup>2</sup> such that

:<math>\displaystyle{e^{-izw/2}F(z,w)=W(z,w)v.}</math>

Then ''W'' leaves the space of entire vectors invariant and satisfies

:<math>\displaystyle{W(z_1,w_1)W(z_2,w_2)= e^{i(z_1w_2-w_1z_2)} W(z_1+z_2,w_1+w_2).}</math>

Moreover, for ''g'' in SL(2,'''R''')

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi(g) W(u)\pi(g)^*=W(gu),}</math>

using the natural action of SL(2,'''R''') on '''C'''<sup>2</sup>.

Formally

:<math>\displaystyle{W(z,w)^*=W(-\overline{z},-\overline{w}).}</math>

==Oscillator semigroup==
There is a natural double cover of the Olshanski semigroup ''H'', and its closure <math>\overline{H}</math> that extends the double cover of SU(1,1) corresponding to the metaplectic group. It is given by pairs (''g'', γ) where ''g'' is an element of ''H'' or its closure

:<math>\displaystyle{g=\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d\end{pmatrix}}</math>

and γ is a square root of ''a''.

Such a choice determines a unique branch of

:<math>\displaystyle{\left(-\overline{b} z + \overline{d}\right)^{1\over 2}}</math>

for |''z''| < 1.

The unitary operators π(''g'') for ''g'' in SL(2,'''R''') satisfy

:<math> \displaystyle{\pi(g) W(u) =W(g\cdot u) \pi(g), \,\,\, \pi(g)^*W(u) =W(g^{-1}\cdot u)\pi(g)^*}</math>

for ''u'' in '''C'''<sup>2</sup>.

An element ''g'' of the complexification  SL(2,'''C''') is said to ''implementable'' if there is a bounded operator ''T'' such that it and its adjoint leave the space of entire vectors for ''W'' invariant, both have dense images and satisfy the  covariance relations

:<math> \displaystyle{T W(u) =W(g\cdot u) T, \,\,\, T^* W(u) =W(g^{\dagger}\cdot u)T^*}</math>

for ''u'' in '''C'''<sup>2</sup>. The implementing operator ''T'' is uniquely determined up to multiplication by a non-zero scalar.

The implementable elements form a semigroup, containing SL(2,'''R'''). Since the representation has positive energy, the bounded compact self-adjoint operators

:<math>\displaystyle{S_0(t)=e^{-tL_0}}</math>

for ''t'' > 0 implement the group elements in exp ''C''<sub>1</sub>.

It follows that all elements of the Olshanski semigroup and its closure are implemented.

Maximality of the Olshanki semigroup implies that no other elements of SL(2,'''C''') are implemented. Indeed, otherwise every element of SL(2,'''C''') would be implemented by a bounded operator, which would condradict the non-invertibility of the operators ''S''<sub>0</sub>(''t'') for ''t'' > 0.

In the Schrödinger representation the operators ''S''<sub>0</sub>(''t'') for ''t'' > 0 are given by Mehler's formula. They are [[contraction (operator theory)|contraction operators]], positive and in every [[Schatten class operator|Schatten class]]. Moreover, they leave invariant each of the Sobolev spaces. The same formula is true for <math>\Re\, t > 0</math> by analytic continuation.

It can be seen directly in the Fock model that the implementing operators can be chosen so that they define an ordinary representation of the double cover of ''H'' constructed above. The corresponding semigroup of contraction operators is called the '''oscillator semigroup'''. The '''extended oscillator semigroup''' is obtained by taking the semidirect product with the operators ''W''(''u''). These operators lie in every Schatten class and leave invariant the Sobolev spaces and the space of entire vectors for ''W''.

The decomposition

:<math>\displaystyle{\overline{H} = G\cdot \exp \overline{C}}</math>

corresponds at the operator level to the [[Polar decomposition#Bounded operators on Hilbert space|polar decomposition of bounded operators]].

Moreover, since any matrix in ''H'' is conjugate to a diagonal matrix by elements in ''H'' or ''H''<sup>−1</sup>, every operator in the oscillator semigroup is [[Contraction (operator theory)#Quasi-similarity|quasi-similar]] to an operator ''S''<sub>0</sub>(''t'') with <math> \Re t > 0</math>. In particular it has the same spectrum consisting of simple eigenvalues.

In the Fock model, if the element ''g'' of the Olshanki semigroup ''H'' corresponds to the matrix

:<math>\displaystyle{\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d\end{pmatrix},}</math>

the corresponding operator is given by

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi(g,\gamma)f(w) = {1\over \pi}\iint_{\mathbf C} K(w,\overline{z}) f(z) e^{-|z|^2}\,dxdy,}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{K(w,z)=\gamma^{-1} \cdot \exp\,{1\over 2a}(c z^2 + 2wz - b w^2)}</math>

and γ is a square root of ''a''. Operators π(''g'',γ) for ''g'' in the semigroup ''H'' are exactly those that are [[Hilbert–Schmidt operator]]s and correspond to kernels of the form

:<math>\displaystyle{K(w,z)=C\cdot \exp\,{1\over 2}(p z^2 + 2qwz + r w^2)}</math>

for which the complex symmetric matrix 
 
:<math>\displaystyle{\begin{pmatrix} p& q \\ q & r\end{pmatrix}}</math>

has [[operator norm]] strictly less than one.

Operators in the extended oscillator semigroup are given by similar expressions with additional linear terms in ''z'' and ''w'' appearing in the exponential.

In the disk model for  the two irreducible components of the metaplectic representation, the corresponding operators are given by

:<math>\displaystyle{\pi_\pm(g)F_\pm(z)= (-\overline{b} z + \overline{d})^{-1\pm 1/2} F_\pm\left({\overline{a} z -\overline{c}\over -\overline{b} z + \overline{d}}\right).}</math>

It is also possible to give an explicit formula for the contraction operators corresponding to ''g'' in ''H'' in the Schrödinger representation, It was by this formula that {{harvtxt|Howe|1988}} introduced the oscillator semigroup as an explicit family of operators on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''').<ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989|pages=223–255}}</ref>

In fact consider the [[Siegel upper half plane]] consisting of symmetric complex 2x2 matrices with positive definite real part:

:<math>\displaystyle{Z=\begin{pmatrix}A & B \\ B & D\end{pmatrix}}</math>

and define the kernel

:<math>\displaystyle{K_Z(x,y)=e^{-(Ax^2 +2B xy +Dy^2)}.}</math>

with corresponding operator

:<math>\displaystyle{T_Zf(x)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty K_Z(x,y)f(y)\, dy}</math>

for ''f'' in ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''').

Then direct computation gives

:<math>\displaystyle{T_{Z_1}T_{Z_2}=(D_1+A_2)^{-1/2}T_{Z_3}}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{Z_3=\begin{pmatrix} A_1 -B_1^2(D_1+A_2)^{-1} &-B_1B_2(D_1+A_2)^{-1} \\-B_1B_2(D_1+A_2)^{-1} & D_2 -B_2^2(D_1+A_2)^{-1}\end{pmatrix}.}</math>

Moreover,

:<math>\displaystyle{T_Z^*= T_{Z^+}}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{Z^+=\begin{pmatrix} \overline{D} & \overline{B} \\ \overline{B} & \overline{A}\end{pmatrix}.}</math>

By Mehler's formula for <math>\Re\, t > 0</math>

:<math>\displaystyle{e^{-t(P^2+Q^2)} = (\mathrm{cosech}\, 2t)^{1\over 2}\cdot T_{Z(t)}}</math>

with

:<math>\displaystyle{Z(t)=\begin{pmatrix} \coth 2t & -\mathrm{ cosech}\, 2t \\  -\mathrm{ cosech}\, 2t & \coth 2t\end{pmatrix}.}</math>

The oscillator semigroup is obtained by taking only matrices with ''B'' ≠ 0. From the above, this condition is closed under composition.

A normalized operator can be defined by

:<math>\displaystyle{S_Z=B^{1\over 2}\cdot T_Z.}</math>

The choice of a square root determines a double cover.

In this case ''S''<sub>''Z''</sub> corresponds to the element

:<math>\displaystyle{g=\begin{pmatrix} -DB^{-1} & DAB^{-1}-B \\ B^{-1} & -AB^{-1}\end{pmatrix}}</math>

of the Olshankii semigroup ''H''.

Moreover, ''S''<sub>''Z''</sub> is a strict contraction:

:<math>\displaystyle{ \|S_Z\|<1.}</math>

It follows also that

:<math>\displaystyle{S_{Z_1} S_{Z_2} =\pm S_{Z_3}.}</math>

==Weyl calculus==
For a function ''a''(''x'',''y'') on '''R'''<sup>2</sup> = '''C''', let

:<math>\displaystyle{\psi(a)={1\over 2\pi}\int\widehat{a}(x,y) W(x,y)\, dx dy.}</math>

So

:<math>\displaystyle{\psi(a)f(x) =\int K(x,y)f(y)\, dy,}</math>

where

:<math>\displaystyle{K(x,y)=\int a (t, {x+y\over 2})e^{i(x-y)t}\, dt.}</math>

Defining in general

:<math> \displaystyle{W(F)={1\over 2\pi} \int F(z)W(z)\,dxdy,}</math>

the product of two such operators is given by the formula

:<math>\displaystyle{W(F)W(G)=W(F\star G),}</math>

where the [[convolution#convolution on groups|twisted convolution]] or [[Moyal product]] is given by

:<math>\displaystyle{F\star G(z)={1\over 2\pi}  \int F(z_1)G(z_2-z_1) e^{i(x_1y_2-y_1x_2)}\, dx_1dy_1.}</math>

The smoothing operators correspond to ''W''(''F'') or ψ(''a'') with ''F'' or ''a'' Schwartz functions on '''R'''<sup>2</sup>. The corresponding operators ''T'' have kernels that are Schwartz functions. They carry each Sobolev space into the Schwartz functions. Moreover, every bounded operator on ''L''<sup>2</sup> ('''R''') having this property has this form.

For the operators ψ(''a'') the Moyal product translates into the '''Weyl symbolic calculus'''. Indeed, if the Fourier transforms of ''a'' and ''b'' have compact support than

:<math>\displaystyle{\psi(a)\psi(b) =\psi(a\circ b),}</math>

where

:<math>a\circ b= \sum_{n\ge 0} {i^n\over n!} \left({\partial^2\over \partial x_1\partial y_2} -{\partial^2\over \partial y_1\partial x_2}\right)^n a\otimes b|_{\mathrm{diagonal}}.</math>

This follows because in this case ''b'' must extend to an entire function on '''C'''<sup>2</sup> by the [[Paley-Wiener theorem]].

This calculus can be extended to a broad class of symbols, but the simplest corresponds to convolution by a class of functions or distributions that all have the form ''T'' + ''S'' where ''T'' is a distribution of compact with [[singular support]] concentrated at 0 and where ''S'' is a Schwartz function. This class contains the operators ''P'', ''Q'' as well as ''D''<sup>1/2</sup> and ''D''<sup>−1/2</sup> where ''D'' is the harmonic oscillator.

The ''m''th order symbols ''S''<sup>''m''</sup> are given by smooth functions ''a'' satisfying

:<math>\displaystyle{|\partial^\alpha a(z)| \le C_\alpha (1+|z|)^{m-|\alpha|}}</math>

for all α and Ψ<sup>''m''</sup> consists of all operators ψ(''a'') for such ''a''.

If ''a'' is in  ''S''<sup>''m''</sup> and χ is a smooth function of compact support equal to 1 near 0, then

:<math>\displaystyle{\widehat{a} =\chi \widehat{a} + (1-\chi)\widehat{a}=T+S,}</math>

with ''T'' and ''S'' as above.

These operators preserve the Schwartz functions and satisfy;

:<math>\displaystyle{\Psi^m\cdot \Psi^m \subseteq \Psi^{m+n},\,\,\,\, [\Psi^m,\Psi^n]\subseteq \Psi^{m+n-2}.}</math>

The operators ''P'' and ''Q'' lie in  Ψ<sup>1</sup> and ''D'' lies in Ψ<sup>2</sup>.

'''Properties:'''

*A zeroth order symbol defines a bounded operator on ''L''<sup>2</sup>('''R''').
*''D''<sup>−1</sup> lies in  Ψ<sup>−2</sup>
*If ''R'' = ''R''* is smoothing, then ''D'' + ''R'' has a complete set of eigenvectors ''f''<sub>''n''</sub> in <math>\mathcal{S}</math> with (''D'' + ''R'') ''f''<sub>''n''</sub> = λ<sub>''n''</sub> ''f''<sub>''n''</sub> and  λ<sub>''n''</sub> tends to ≈ as ''n'' tends to ≈.
*''D''<sup>1/2</sup> lies in  Ψ<sup>1</sup> and hence ''D''<sup>−1/2</sup> lies in Ψ<sup>−1</sup>, since ''D''<sup>−1/2</sup> = ''D''<sup>1/2</sup> ·''D''<sup>−1</sup>
*Ψ<sup>−1</sup> consists of compact operators, Ψ<sup>−''s''</sup> consists of trace-class operators for ''s'' > 1 and Ψ<sup>''k''</sup> carries ''H<sub>m</sub>'' into ''H''<sub>''m''–''k''</sub>.
* <math>\displaystyle{\mathrm{Tr}\, \psi(a) = \int a}</math>

The proof of boundedness of {{harvtxt|Howe|1980}} is particularly simple: if

:<math>\displaystyle{T_{a,b} v=(v,b)a,}</math>

then

:<math>\displaystyle{T_{W(z)a,b}=e^{|z|^2/2} [W(z) T_{a,E_0}W(z)^{-1}T_{E_0,b}],}</math>

where the bracketed operator has norm less than <math>\|a\|\cdot \|b\|</math>. So if ''F'' is supported in |''z''| ≤ ''R'', then

:<math>\displaystyle{\|W(F)\| \le e^{R^2/2}\|\widehat{F}\|_\infty.}</math>

The property of ''D''<sup>−1</sup> is proved by taking

:<math>\displaystyle{S=\psi(a)}</math>

with

:<math>\displaystyle{a(z)={1\over |z|^2 +1}.}</math>

Then ''R'' = ''I'' – ''DS'' lies in  Ψ<sup>−1</sup>, so that

:<math>\displaystyle{A\sim S + SR +SR^2 + \cdots}</math>

lies in Ψ<sup>−2</sup> and ''T'' = ''DA'' – ''I'' is smoothing. Hence

:<math> \displaystyle{D^{-1}= A - D^{-1}T}</math>

lies in   Ψ<sup>−2</sup>  since ''D''<sup>−1</sup> ''T'' is smoothing.

The property for ''D''<sup>1/2</sup> is established similarly by constructing ''B'' in Ψ<sup>1/2</sup> with real symbol such that ''D'' – ''B''<sup>4</sup> is a smoothing operator. Using the [[holomorphic functional calculus]] it can be checked that ''D''<sup>1/2</sup> – ''B''<sup>2</sup> is a smoothing operator.

The boundedness result above was used by {{harvtxt|Howe|1980}} to establish the more general inequality of  [[Alberto Calderón]] and Remi Vaillancourt for [[pseudodifferential operator]]s. An alternative proof that applies more generally to [[Fourier integral operator]]s was given by {{harvtxt|Howe|1988}}. He showed that such operators can be expressed as integrals over the oscillator semigroup and then estimated using the [[Cotlar-Stein lemma]].<ref>{{harvnb|Folland|1989|pp=121–129}}</ref>

==Applications and generalizations==

===Theory for finite abelian groups===
{{harvtxt|Weil|1964}} noted that the formalism of the Stone–von Neumann theorem and the oscillator representation of the symplectic group extends from the real numbers '''R''' to any [[locally compact abelian group]]. A particularly simple example is provided by [[finite abelian group]]s, where the proofs are either elementary or simplifications of the proofs for '''R'''.<ref>{{harvnb|Mumford|Nori|Norman|2006}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Igusa|1972}}</ref>

Let ''A'' be a finite abelian group, written additively, and let ''Q'' be a non-degenerate [[quadratic form]] on ''A'' with values in '''T'''. Thus

:<math>\displaystyle{(a,b)=Q(a)Q(b)Q(a+b)^{-1}}</math>

is a symmetric bilinear form on ''A'' that is non-degenerate, so permits an identification between ''A'' and its [[Pontryagin dual|dual group]] ''A''* = Hom (''A'', '''T''').

Let

:<math>\displaystyle{V=\ell^2(A),}</math>

the space of complex-valued functions on ''A'' with inner product

:<math>\displaystyle{(f,g)=\sum_{x\in A} f(x)\overline{g(x)}.}</math>

Define operators on ''V'' by

:<math>\displaystyle{U(x) f(t)= f(t-x),\,\,\, V(y)f(t)=(y,t) f(t)}</math>

for ''x'', ''y'' in ''A''. Then ''U''(''x'') and ''V''(''y'') are unitary representations of ''A'' on ''V'' satisfying the commutation relations

:<math>\displaystyle{U(x)V(y)=(x,y) V(y) U(x).}</math>
